case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Crown Life Insurance Company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 999 of 1964 filed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 999 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from order dated March 25, 1954 of Life Insurance Tribunal, Bombay in Case No. 27 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated March 25, 1954 of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Bombay in Case No. 27 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant is Life Insurance Corporation of India.

anchor.surface_text: by the appellant, the Life Insurance Corporation of India on the taking over of the business of the respondent

facts.text: Respondent is Crown Life Insurance Company incorporated in Canada.

anchor.surface_text: payment of compensation to the respondent, the Crown Life Insurance Company, which is incorporated in Canada,

facts.text: Appellant took over business of respondent under Life Insurance Corporation Act No. 31 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: on the taking over of the business of the respondent by the appellant under the Act.

facts.text: Respondent claimed Rs. 27,86,658 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed Rs. 27,86,658 as compensation while the appellant was prepared to pay Rs.

facts.text: Appellant prepared to pay Rs. 1,11,466 as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: while the appellant was prepared to pay Rs. 1,11,466.

facts.text: Respondent's life insurance fund was always in deficit before the Act came into force.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed that as its life insurance fund was always in deficit before the Act came into force,

facts.text: Appellant claimed surplus of Rs. 27,86,658 in life insurance fund under cl. d of paragraph 4 Part B First Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on the other hand claimed that under that cl. d , there was a surplus of Rs. 27,86,658

facts.text: Under cl. d, appellant debited Rs. 26,75,192 towards liabilities of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore under cl. d a sum of Rs. 26,75,192 was to be debited towards the liabilities of the respondent.

facts.text: Life Insurance Tribunal accepted respondent's contention and awarded compensation at Rs. 27,86,658.

anchor.surface_text: The Insurance Tribunal has accepted the contention put forward on behalf of the respondent ... awarded compensation at Rs. 27,86,658.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by this order, the appellant got special leave from this Court and that is how the matter has come up before us.

facts.text: Business of respondent in India always showed deficit in Form I of Fourth Schedule to Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is not in dispute that the business of the respondent in India always had shown a deficit in form I.

facts.text: Respondent paid bonuses to policy-holders out of global surplus in cash.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent used to pay bonuses to its policy-holders out of its global surplus and these payments were made in cash.

facts.text: Respondent repatriated excess assets of about Rs. 15 or 16 lakhs under s.35 of the Act with permission of Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the respondent has taken away excess assets with the permission of the Central Government under s. 35, to the tune of about rupees fifteen or sixteen lakhs.

facts.text: Respondent executed instrument of trust under s.27(6) Insurance Act with State Bank of India as trustee.

anchor.surface_text: Such an instrument of trust was executed by the respondent and the State Bank of India was the trustee of the fund required to be kept under s. 27(1) read with s. 27(6).

facts.text: Funds brought by respondent from outside to cover deficit were never put in revenue account Form D.

anchor.surface_text: funds brought in by the respondent from outside to cover the deficit were never put in the revenue account

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore dismiss the appeal with costs to the respondent.

issues.text: the interpretation of the words life insurance fund as used in paragraph 4 of Part B of the First Schedule to the Life Insurance Corporation Act, No. 31 of 1956

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal by special leave from the order of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Bombay, is the interpretation of the words life insurance fund as used in paragraph 4 of Part B of the First Schedule to the Life Insurance Corporation Act, No. 31 of 1956, hereinafter referred

issues.text: what the words life insurance fund mean under the Insurance Act and whether the context of cl. d of the said paragraph 4 requires otherwise

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore to turn to the Insurance Act first to find out the meaning of the words life insurance fund as given therein and then to see whether the context of cl. d of the said paragraph 4 requires otherwise. If we come to the conclusion that it does not require

anchor.surface_text: Now we come to the last question whether there is anything in the Act which requires that we should give a different meaning to the words life insurance fund in cl. d of the aforesaid 4th paragraph. We have already referred to s. 2(10) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: But apart from this rationale behind cl. d we find that the language of Part A and Part B of the First Schedule relating to principles for determining compensation

arguments.claim: Tribunal rejected appellant's contention

anchor.surface_text: It has rejected the contention raised on behalf of the appellant and has in consequence awarded compensation at Rs. 27,86,658.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e appellant even 96 of the share capital may be lost to an insurance companypany, whose business is being taken over by the Life Insurance Corporation

holdings.text: The words 'life insurance fund' as used in cl. d of paragraph 4 of Part B of the First Schedule to the Life Insurance Corporation Act, No. 31 of 1956 have the same meaning as that given to them in s. 10(2) of the Insurance Act read with s. 11 and form D of the Third Schedule to the Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no doubt that the tribunal was right in its conclusion that the words life insurance fund as used in cl. d of the aforesaid 4th paragraph have the same meaning as that given to them in s. 10 2  of the Insurance Act read with s. 1 1 and form D of the Third Schedule to the Insurance Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(10) LIC Act incorporates meanings from Insurance Act unless context requires otherwise; consistent usage in Insurance Act via s.10(2), Form D, Form I; no contextual departure in LIC Act; rationale tied to s.49(1); harmonious Parts A/B; avoids absurdity with s.35.

holdings.text: The words 'life insurance fund' under the Insurance Act have a definite meaning assigned under s.10(2) read with s.11(c) and Form D of the Third Schedule, being the balance arrived at in the revenue account for life insurance business.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt therefore that the words life insurance fund under the Insurance Act have got the meaning assigned to it under s. 10 2  read with s. 11 and form D of the Third Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory scheme: s.10(2) constitutes separate fund from life receipts; s.11(c) mandates Form D revenue account; balance therein forms life insurance fund in balance sheet Form A.

holdings.text: The words 'life insurance fund' have no other or different meaning under the Insurance Act in provisions like s.56(2), s.58(3), or Regulation 7 Part I First Schedule; all consistent with s.10(2) meaning.

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore reject the contention on behalf of the appellant that the words life insurance fund have any meaning other than that assigned to them in s. 10 2  of the Insurance Act so far as that Act is concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of cited provisions shows consistent reference to surplus per Form I within s.10(2) fund; marginal notes and plurals do not alter; harmonious reading throughout Act.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the context of the LIC Act, including s.2(10), Parts A/B First Schedule, or s.35, that requires a different meaning to 'life insurance fund' in cl. d from that in the Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is nothing in the context of the Act which requires that a different meaning should be given to these words.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(10) mandates Insurance Act meanings unless context otherwise; rationale of cl.d mirrors s.49(1) for past surplus only; Parts A/B distinguish allocation per Form I; s.35 uses explicit total assets/liabilities, contrasting cl.d.

holdings.text: Assets required to be invested under s.27(1) Insurance Act to cover deficit in life insurance fund do not form part of the life insurance fund unless included in revenue account Form D.

anchor.surface_text: It is only such moneys which are included in form D and which are not of capital nature that form part of the life insurance fund.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.27(1) is safety for policyholders, not constitutive of fund; Form D 'other income' excludes capital infusions not routed through revenue; here, funds never entered Form D, Form I showed deficit.

holdings.text: Since the respondent's life insurance fund always showed a deficit in Form I of the Fourth Schedule to the Insurance Act, there was no surplus and no liability under cl. d of para 4 Part B First Schedule LIC Act; compensation is Rs. 27,86,658.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the appeal must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of 'life insurance fund' meaning and Form I deficit to facts; no past surplus allocation under s.49(1); Tribunal award upheld.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore dismiss the appeal with costs to the respondent.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed upholding the Tribunal's award of Rs. 27,86,658 as compensation to the respondent
